Considering adaptive variation increased the predicted potential for interspecific competition, through increased range overlap. Range overlap between species in Iberia was predicted to decrease under future conditions (84% reduction, from 10.5 to 1.7% of Iberia), but estimations of future range overlap were more than 4 times higher when the ranges of hot–dry and cold–wet individuals were combined (7.1%;
SI Appendix, Fig. S3 ). Changing species interactions have already been implicated in population declines and extinctions related to climate change ( 30). Moreover, spatially explicit simulations of multispecies responses to climate change show that when interspecific competition is included in future models, preadapted species displace maladapted species ( 31), which is likely to be the outcome of increased future range overlap among the warm-adapted M. escalerai and the more cold-adapted M. crypticus.
